children.name: analysis
children.definition: phân tích
examples: a)a detailed examination of something in order to understand it better, especially when this involves studying a large amount of information: phân tích, bài phân tích
analysis of
He’s written a careful analysis of the drug problem in America.
adetailed analysisof the week’s news
Further analysis of the data is needed.
An analysis of data from Australia shows that skin cancer is on the increase.
do/carry out/conduct an analysis
They were doing some type ofstatistical analysis.
in the final analysisafter all other ideas have been considered
In the final analysis, it is the better organized party that will probably win.
b)the way in which sb describes a situation or problem, and says what causes it to happen
analysis of
Do you agree with Marx’s analysis of the failure of free-market capitalism?
a detailed/in-depth analysisa detailed analysis of the firm’s earnings
data analysisthe use of databases for data analysis

children.name: an in-depth analysis
children.definition: detailed analysis
examples: )an in-depth analysis of global warming

children.name: a careful/close analysis
examples: Students learn to make a close analysis of the texts.

children.name: a brief analysis
examples: Let’s start with a brief analysis of the situation.

children.name: statistical analysis
children.definition: using statistics
examples: Their research was based on statistical analysis.

children.name: a critical analysis
children.definition: that makes judgements about how good or bad something is
examples: Write a critical analysis of the following poem.

children.name: economic/political/scientific etc analysis
examples: His book provided a scientific analysis of human behaviour.

children.name: be based on an analysis of something
examples: This work has been based entirely on an analysis of large mammals.

children.name: do/carry out/perform/conduct an analysis
examples: No similar analysis has been done in this country.

children.name: provide/produce an analysis
examples: The report provided an analysis of the problems we need to address.

children.name: an analysis shows something
examples: DNA analysis shows that the blood and the saliva come from the same person.

children.name: an analysis suggests/indicates something
examples: Our analysis suggests that these problems are widespread.

children.name: research
children.definition: (alsoresearchesformal) careful detailed work that is done in order to find out more about a subject, especially as a part of a scientific or academic project
examples: research into/on
research into the causes of cancer
Gould was helped in his researches by local naturalists.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say'make research'. Saydo researchorcarry out research.

children.name: do/carry out research
children.definition: alsoconduct researchformal
examples: The research was carried out by a team of scientists at Edinburgh University.|Little research has been conducted into the subject.

children.name: undertake researchformal
children.definition: start or do research
examples: They are planning to undertake research into the genetic causes of the disease.

children.name: scientific research
examples: Our conclusions are based on scientific research.

children.name: medical research
examples: The charity raises money for medical research.

children.name: historical research
examples: This is a fascinating piece of historical research.

children.name: basic research
children.definition: the most important or most necessary area of research
examples: He wants to conduct basic research into the nature of human cells.

children.name: extensive research
children.definition: research that examines a lot of information and details
examples: Extensive research has proved the theory wrong.

children.name: painstaking research
children.definition: very careful and thorough research
examples: She spent years carrying out painstaking historical research.

children.name: pioneering research
children.definition: research that produces completely new information
examples: Watson did pioneering research on the long-term effects of dieting.

children.name: a research project/programme
examples: The research project will be funded by the Medical Research Council.

children.name: research findings
children.definition: what is discovered by a piece of research
examples: He will present his research findings at the conference.

children.name: research work
examples: Doctor Fox received world-wide acclaim for her research work on breast cancer.

children.name: a research team
examples: The professor will head a research team working on the effects of climatic change on agriculture.

children.name: a research student
examples: He supervised many research students.

children.name: a research grant
children.definition: money for doing research
examples: Have you applied for a research grant?

children.name: an area/field of research
examples: This is a very exciting area of research.

children.name: a piece of research
examples: A recent piece of research shows why marriages break up.

children.name: a body of research
children.definition: results from several pieces of research
examples: There is a large body of research which indicates that passive smoking causes cancer.

children.name: study
children.definition: a piece of work that is done to find out more about a particular subject or problem, and usually includes a written report :
examples: Recent studies show that women still get paid a lot less than men.
study of/into/on
a study of Australian wild birds
The study was carried out between January and May 2008.

children.name: do a study/carry out a study
children.definition: alsoconduct a studyformal
examples: The scientists are carrying out a study into the effects of global warming.

children.name: a study finds something
examples: The study found that men were more likely to take risks.

children.name: a study shows something
examples: Studies have shown that the drug works.

children.name: a study suggests/indicates something
examples: A British study suggests that older drivers are safer drivers.

children.name: a study reveals something
children.definition: shows something, especially something surprising
examples: A recent study revealed that 74% of donuts are bought on impulse.

children.name: a study confirms something
children.definition: shows that something is true
examples: The study confirms what we all know – smoking is also bad for the people around you.

children.name: a study aims to do something
examples: The study aimed to identify the housing needs of local people.

children.name: publish a study
examples: The study was published in the British Medical Journal.

children.name: fund a study
children.definition: pay for it
examples: The study was funded by a major US drugs company.

children.name: commission a study
children.definition: ask someone to carry out a study
examples: The government has commissioned a study into the health of residents living near the power station.

children.name: a research study
examples: Research studies have found that young people are drinking no more than they were 20 years ago.

children.name: a detailed study
children.definition: alsoan in-depth study
examples: They carried out a detailed study into the effects of the disease on mice.

children.name: a two-year/three-month etc study
examples: They are engaged in a five-year study into the effects of calcium on bone health.

children.name: a huge/massive study
examples: The journal published the results of a massive study of 87,000 women.

children.name: a previous/earlier study
examples: The report is a summary of the work done in earlier studies.

children.name: a pilot study
children.definition: one done to find out if something will be successful
examples: The government has just completed a pilot study, with some encouraging results.

children.name: a feasibility study
children.definition: one done to find out if something is possible or practical
examples: They commissioned a feasibility study into re-opening the whole railway line.

children.name: the aims of a study
examples: The aims of this study are to examine the reliability of current techniques.

children.name: the results/findings of a study
examples: The results of this study suggest that the drug is effective in over 80% of cases.|His research confirmed the findings of earlier studies.

children.name: to study sth in order to discover new facts
study
children.definition: to examine sth carefully, do tests on it etc, in order to find out more about it and discover new facts:nghiên cứu
examples: She spent several years studying the behaviour of gorillas in Africa.
The discovery will be of great interest to scientists studying the origins of the universe.
Goodall was studying the behavior of chimpanzees in the wild.
The scientists were studying the action of a protein called ubiquitin.

children.name: study how/what/why etc
examples: They’re studying how stress affects body chemistry.
NASA has used the space shuttle to study how materials perform in a weightless environment.

children.name: analyse
children.definition: UK /analyzeUS  to carefully examine information, reports, the results of tests etc, in order to understand sth better:phân tích
examples: We use a special computer program to analyse all the sales figures.
We will have to analyze the results of the survey before making any decisions.
Researchers analysed the purchases of 6300 households.
be analysed for
Water samples taken from streams were analysedforcontamination by chemicals.
analyst[C] B2 sb whose job is to think about something carefully in order to understand it, and often to advise other people about it : chuyên gia phân tích
Political analystsexpect the Conservatives to win.
investment/financial/business analyst
Cleary has been working as acomputer analystin Winchester.
analytical[adj] C1 thinking about things in a detailed and intelligent way, so that you can examine and understand things : phân tích
analytical mindóc phân tích
She’s got an analytical mind.
analytical method/techniques/approach/skills
During the course, students will develop their analytical skills.
Some students have a more analyticalapproachto learning.

children.name: do research
children.definition: do/conduct/ carry out research to study a subject in a careful, detailed way, in order to discover new information or produce new ideas about it:tiến hành nghiên cứu
examples: Dr. Cooper is a surgeon who does research at Harvard University.
The organization’s laboratories conduct advanced research in areas such as electronics, biotechnology, and engineering.

children.name: do/conduct/carry out research into/on
examples: Baskin has made several trips to Nicaragua to carry out research on land distribution.

children.name: research
children.definition: to study a subject in a careful, detailed way, in order to discover new information or produce new ideas about it:nghiên cứu
examples: Vargas began researching his family’s history 12 years ago.
It is important to research the market fully before offering a new product for sale.
He’s been researching material for a documentary.
research intoUK
Doctors researching into the causes of the disease believe they may have found a cure.
Ten years ago I began researching into the role of women in trade unions.
Register:In everyday English, people often use the expressiondo researchrather than the verbto research:
She’s beendoing some researchinto the history of the area.
researcher[C] B2
a television/political researcher

children.name: to pay attention to the way a situation develops
keep an eye on
children.definition: /ˌkiːp ən ˈaɪ ɒn/  to watch a situation carefully over a period of time, especially so that you are prepared for anything bad that might happen:

children.name: để mắt tới ( ý nói theo dõi để đánh giá )
examples: ▪ If I were you, I’d keep an eye on house prices for a while before you decide to sell.

children.name: keep a close/careful eye on something
examples: ▪ Government experts will be keeping a close eye on the new currency to see whether it proves successful.

children.name: watch
children.definition: /wɒtʃǁwɑːtʃ, wɔːtʃ/
examples: ▪ Both candidates are watching the opinion polls carefully.

children.name: watch sb do sth
examples: ▪ We have watched hundreds of small firms collapse over the last few years.

children.name: watch how/when/what etc
examples: ▪ Many swimmers are videoed during training so they can watch how their performance improves.

children.name: monitor
children.definition: to carefully watch and check a situation in order to see how it changes over a period of time: theo dõi
examples: Doctors monitored her progress during the night.
We will of course monitor the campaign to assess its effectiveness.
Patients who are given the new drug will be asked to monitor their progress.
The government ismonitoringthe situationclosely.
The temperature iscarefully monitored.

children.name: monitor what/how etc
examples: We need a better system for monitoring what is going on.

children.name: track
children.definition: to record or study the behaviour or development of sb/sth over time : theo dõi
examples: The progress of each student is tracked by computer.
The study tracked the careers of 1226 doctors who trained at the University of Michigan Medical School.

children.name: follow sth up
children.definition: followsthupphrasal verb(US alsofollow up onsth)

children.name: to find out more about something, or take further action connected with it
examples: _The idea sounded interesting and I decided to follow it up.
_He decided to follow up on his initial research and write a book.

children.name: weigh up
children.definition: weighsthupphrasal verb

children.name: to think carefully about the advantages or disadvantages of a situation before making adecision
examples: _I'm weighing up my options before I decide to apply for the job.

children.name: weigh
children.definition: verbCONSIDER

children.name: review
children.definition: to examine, consider, and judge a situation or process carefully in order to see if changes are necessary:
examples: We will review your situation and decide how we can help you.
The decision will be reviewed by the Supreme Court.
The team manager’s position will be reviewed at the end of the season.
The bank will review its security procedures after last week’s attack.

children.name: consider
children.definition: verbSUBJECT/FACT

children.name: measure
children.definition: verbJUDGE

children.name: look at
children.definition: sthphrasal verbto study and think about something, especially in order to decide what to do :
examples: We need to look very carefully at ways of improving our efficiency.
